segments.text: What's the value to a scientist to be established at an institution like Scripps?
A value to a scientist?
Right.
Let me, the question's poorly phrased.
Usually you think of a scientist working out of a very traditional department, that is, department of geophysics or what have you.
But here there seems to be a mixture of scientists working in and around the ocean.
Is that a particular value to a scientist doing research?
Well, I think sometimes, yes, the value, I think, is from the sharing of information from various disciplines.
So that a scientist that scripts, and I think this is true in general of oceanographic institution, is that the science is not as

compartmentalize in oceanography as it might be in a more traditional university where you have departments of physics, chemistry, mathematics, in which a man might carry out his entire scientific career in one fairly narrow field.
Oceanography doesn't have these sharp boundaries, and when
One sees that right from the beginning when you go to sea and share the use of a ship with many other disciplines.
And so that, in a sense, is an advantage.
It's a broadening experience to work in an oceanographic institution.
Now, were you the driving force behind the Operation Mid-Pack?
I wouldn't say I was the driving force.
I think
The most important person in MIDPAC was Roger Bell.
He was the leader of the expedition.
I was, my function, I remember, I was chairman of what they called a joint planning committee.
We had the, we wanted to have a two-ship expedition.
That was mainly my interest because I wanted to do seismic refreshment work before I had a two-ship.
Scripps Institution only had one ocean-going ship.
That was the Horizon.
There was a similar interest in doing oceanographic exploration, geophysical, at the Naval Electronics Lab.
So we got together.
This was largely through the efforts of Roger Revelle.
and formed a joint expedition of the two laboratories.
And my function there was to be chairman of a committee where we met about once a week for several months before the cruise to discuss what we were going to do.
Was the Mid-Pac Expedition related to the later Nor-Pac Expedition?
I don't believe so, except the name.
NORPAC was an area describing an expedition studying the North Pacific.
The MIDPAC was studying the Mid-Pacific.
But I don't believe they were too directly related.
I had nothing to do with NORPAC.
What sort of information about the
Well, there were a variety of projects done.
It's hard for me to remember all of the things that were done.
There were several projects studying the morphology of the ocean bottom through echo sounding.
We were doing studies of ocean bottom structures through seismic refraction methods.
expedition to study heat flow also.
Of course, bottom coring was very important.
The first time we used the piston core, we had a kind of a new device at that time developed by Kuhlenberg, a Swedish oceanographer.
So we had piston cores.
We had gravity cores.
and taking samples of the seafloor, taking temperature probes, and a variety of things.
It would be hard for me just informally like this to really summarize the whole thing, but in a way it was a model for many expeditions to come later on, like Capricorn and other expeditions.
That was exactly what I was interested in, was this idea of it being a model for later expeditions, how it's usually characterized.
What did it do in your particular research?
What direction did it take you after mid-pack?
Oh, I think it demonstrated, let's say it demonstrated for us for the first time that we could go out and do, use seismic refraction methods to

let's say to learn about the structure of down to the upper mantle and so it there was quite a lot of new information gained in mid-pack which certainly justified us continuing it to other oceans other parts of the ocean to see
if what we learned on MITPAC was typical of the ocean, and what the differences of similarities were.
So in that sense, the success of MITPAC did stimulate work and the continuing work in my field as well as in many other fields.
It's really like the study of...
of the heat flow from the ocean bottom, for example.
The initial results on mid-pack were very important in encouraging further work in that field.
Do you enjoy the actual expeditions of oceanography more so than the theoretical and laboratory work?
Yes, I enjoy...
out at sea more than interpreting the data.
Excuse me.
Now, what do you consider your most important accomplishment in oceanography?
Oh, gee.
Oh, I guess maybe what I've done in
in the general field of moho hunting or seismic refraction studies of ocean structure.
In terms of the length of time I've spent in doing that and the quantity of data in the archives.
Would you explain what elastic anastrophe is?
Anisotropy.
Is it anisoptery?
Anisotropy.
Right.
Yeah, well, that's really part.
Let's see, I guess you're referring to something which is really part of this study I'm mentioning of the ocean bottom structure.
In that study, we measure the velocity of the waves under the ocean bottom.

The objective of this work has always been mainly to achieve penetration through the crustal rocks, which form sort of a thin veneer over the bulk of the earth, to penetrate through that crust into the real earth material, the mantle.
The great bulk of the earth is called the mantle.
That's the solid exterior of the earth that's
about 3,000 to 4,000 kilometers thick and lies above the molten core.
We found that the velocity of this mantle, the upper part of the mantle right below the crust, that its velocity depended on direction of travel.
And in other words, it was not isotropic.
Isotropic means that the properties are the same regardless of what direction, but it's anisotropic.
And a good deal of our work here in the last few years has been studying this anisotropy, attempting to measure it and, if possible, learn something about what causes it.
Well, why did you hypothesize about the upper mantle of the ocean in terms of exhibiting it?
Was there any clue you had that the upper mantle might exhibit this?
The idea that it was anisotropic came not from our work, but from other people.
The principal one here is Harry Hess, who studied anisotropy
of the rocks that are believed to be typical of the rocks that come from the upper mantle.
He was a geologist, one of his specialties.
He was a very broad-thinking geologist, but one of his specialties was studying these rocks in a microscope.
These were samples of rocks that came from various places where it was believed that they were extruded
by volcanic process from deep down in the earth, and therefore represented .

Those, when you look at them in a microscope, you can see that the grains in a specimen, say a small specimen of the size of a few centimeters, that the grains in that specimen are not oriented at random, but are lined up.
And this interested him all
Many years ago, he studied this anisotropy in the little sample.
And so he was aware of this anisotropy in small samples, the thing that was

startling about this anisotropy was that it occurred over long distances hundreds of thousands of miles lined up in order it wasn't surprising to anybody that you'd find this anisotropy in a small material because the crystals that make up the uh the type of material that forms the earth crest are anisotropic crystals the crystals are not
don't have a simple cubical structure, but have a more complex structure.

So both the index of refraction, that's the speed of light through the crystal, and the speed of sound, speed of elastic waves, both of these depend on the direction of propagation through the crystal.
So if the crystals then are lined up,
over a long distance, then you get an effect of velocity being in different directions, similar to what we observe in our seismic experiment.
Well, how is this related to sea floor spreading?
There is an experimental relation
we have found is that the direction of maximum velocity is in the direction that sea floor was spreading at the time the rock was formed.
So the obvious conclusion here is that the process of the rock being formed at the time the ocean bottom was spreading apart
In the process of formation, the crystals are lined up.
Now, the details of how this happened are not known, but there's a clue to that in the observation that the maximum direction of maximum velocity is in the direction of spreading.
And we observed that first in the area right off California, where the sea is bottom that's
directly west of here is formed by east-west spreading, roughly.
It's not exactly east-west.
And we've found that when we first observed this, that the maximum velocity was roughly east-west.
And it turns out that if we compare it in detail with the
estimated the direction of spreading.

Then it agrees almost exactly at 90 degrees by making its first statistical study of all of the stations within the area and comparing the velocity with its direction with the direction of the direction that it was moving at the time it was formed.
You understand?
So this is all fairly recent, too.
It's all in the process of...
In fact, we have a paper in the press right now that's just being submitted to the Geophysical Research Letter giving the latest study of what I'm talking about here.
So it's a fairly complex study, and it's going on now, isn't it?
And all the answers aren't in yet.
But this has been generally the continuous direction of your work the last several years?
Yeah, anisotropy is part of it.
The study of, the whole study of structure, say the velocity structure and how it's related to the geology of the area is continuing also.
Anisotropy is certainly part of it.
How did you as an American scientist
find yourself on the Russian vessels, and how well did you function there?
You seem to know quite a bit already.
I have been invited to participate in some Russian oceanographic ships, and that's through

I guess my acquaintance with Russian scientists initially was the reason I... Actually, it was associated with anisotropy because both times I went aboard a Russian ship, they were conducting experiments to measure anisotropy.
But these were people that I knew previously
before I really got into this field of study of anisotropy.
So let's see, the field that we're in, you see, is an international field in which many countries participate.
And the Russians are Russian geophysicists, oceanographers,
are very active in it, very well supported by the Soviet government.
How did you meet the Russian scientist?
Well, there were two occasions where I had good contact.
One was a meeting which took place at UCLA in 1963.
to discuss the results of the International Geophysical Year.
And this meeting was held just before the international meeting of the IUGG, International Union of Geodesy and Geophysics, which meets periodically every three years.
1963, it met in Berkeley.
Before that, there was a meeting at UCLA to discuss the results of the International Geophysical Year.
The Russians sent large delegations to both meetings.
It was at a time when Russia was opening up, sending people abroad for the first time, and a number of people that I knew only through scientific reputation
and came to this meeting.
And some of these people were people who were participating in this oceanographic work that I participated in at sea with them.
But so my direct contact with them began here in 1963, and then later
they had an International Oceanographic Congress in Moscow, 1966.
And I went to that and met and made contacts again with some of the same people that came over here in the summer of 1963.
And then from that came the suggestion that you go on this vessel?
Well, then I was invited, actually, by Udinsev, an oceanographer at the Institute of Oceanology in Moscow, who was one of those that came over in 1963.
I met UCLA.
As a matter of fact, I invited three of them to come down with me to La Jolla
And they visited me in my home and got to see Scripps Institution of Oceanography.
And then the three of us, the three Russians, wife and I, drove up to Berkeley to the meeting together.
We established it was not only a good scientific contact, but a friendly one as well, so I remained friends.
One is a man, Gleb Udintsev, who has been a leader of quite a number of Russian oceanographic expeditions, and he has invited me to go on two of them.
Well, he's invited me to go on more, but two of them I was able to go on.
Did you have any problem, by the way, receiving clearance to go on the oceanographic vessels?
The Russian oceanographic vessels.
Not that I...
I suppose there may have been a problem in, let's say, a local Russian problem in issuing me the invitation.
I don't know.
I was never aware of that.
Let's see, I...
I think I usually receive the invitation through some official letter through the Academy of Sciences or through the director of the Institute of Oceanology or something like that.
But previously, I've always had sort of an informal invitation if I could.
Udintsev travels quite a bit.
He visits.
He comes here to look.
For example, he is the Russian who is...
essentially in charge of the Russian participation in the deep-sea drilling project.
If you're aware of the deep-sea drilling project, you're aware.
And Russia is a participant in that.
They contribute a million dollars a year or something like that.
I don't know exactly what it is.
But they participate, not only as scientists that go aboard the Glomar Challenger on these cruises, but they also contribute money to it.
This man I'm talking about that's my friend is the principal Russian dealing with the Russian part of participation in that deep-sea drilling project.
So he comes here fairly frequently, not only being on the committee, but because he has participated in the drilling legs of the deep-sea drilling project.
So some of these invitations I get,

informally to me when he comes through and says he's going to have an expedition so-and-so is going to be on it would I be interested in joining it okay later on then I may get a letter from from the some more official letter inviting me there may be some problems of Russian but I was never aware of any problems did you speak Russian I don't speak Russian no
So I do have difficulties aboard ship.

However, not very serious because the Russians, really it's necessary for them to know English because in order for them to publish and have their work known abroad, which they're very anxious to do, they have to have some
knowledge of English, not only to have their articles printed in foreign journals, but to be able to keep up with the literature.
And in this field, it's obligatory for them to know English.
So I had no trouble communicating with the scientific party on ship.
My main problem was with the crew.
The crew members couldn't speak English.
But with the scientific part, there was no problem.
Do you notice any particular difference in approach to science and oceanography from the point of view of the Russians vis-a-vis ourselves?
Oh, I guess so, sure.
Every nationality has some difference in attitudes towards things and so on.
Not basically, though.
I think...

what we're doing what the Russians are doing is an international science and we may I think we have we're technologically ahead of the Russians in many ways we have much better computers than they do for example but basically it's the same we're all working the same field there's no real fundamental differences and
And I go aboard their ship, and they're doing the same thing.
They're towing long streamers behind the ship.
They have air guns banging away, and they have magnetometers going, and they're shooting explosives through seismic refraction.
And they have temperature, measuring heat flow in ocean bottom, taking cores.
And with pretty impressive facilities, too.
I mean, a lot of support, big ships, 70 people in a scientific party.
So there's a lot of similarity and differences, too.
Sure, there's bound to be differences.
It's been suggested to me that possibly the oceanography projects in the Soviet Union are better funded than ours.
Would you agree with that?
Well, in some sense, I suppose, relative to the per capita gross national product, I'm sure it's better funded.
Because, well, let's say they have these big ships that certainly cost a lot more money in dollars to operate than ours do, because they're much smaller.
And they have...
a large, as I say, a large scientific party, and so on and so on.
It's very hard to compare funding in the Soviet Union with funding in the U.S., I think, in terms of dollars and rubles, things like that.
But I think in terms of man-hours expended in the field relative to a per capita gross national product,
It's more than we do, more than we do, yeah.
But whether they really get more result, I don't think they get any more better result, probably not quite as good.
